questions.text: A 63 year old male with triple vessel disease on angiography is planned for CABG. He was put on a cardiopulmonary bypass. The following are the Potential complications of Cardiopulmonary Bypass circuit except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Potential complications of CPB: Bleeding disorders Infection Air embolism Intestinal ischaemia/infarction Microembolisation Myocardial depression Neurological dysfunction Pancreatitis Post-cardiotomy syndrome Pulmonary injury Systemic organ dysfunction Vascular injury

questions.text: A road traffic accident patient presents with breathlessness. Differentiation between cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax is best done by?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Breath sounds Both tension pneumothorax and cardiac tamponade both present with breathlessness, tachypnoea and distended neck veins. Tension pneumothorax features- hyper resonance over the chest and absent breath sounds. Cardiac tamponade - Classically, the presentation consists of venous pressure elevation, decline in arterial pressure with tachycardia, and muffled heart sounds.

Highyeild:

Difference between tension pneumothorax and cardiac tamponade Characteristic Tension Pneumothorax Cardiac Tamponade Etiology Trauma, Spontaneous Idiopathic, Post-MI, Malignancy Pathophysiology Air enters pleural cavity, leading to increased pressure on the lung and mediastinum Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac, leading to increased pressure on the heart Clinical features Shortness of breath, respiratory distress, tracheal deviation, hyperresonant percussion note, decreased breath sounds Beck's triad (hypotension, muffled heart sounds, JVD), pulsus paradoxus, distant heart sounds, dyspnea Imaging Chest X-ray (mediastinal shift, absent lung markings), ultrasound Echocardiography, CT scan Treatment Needle decompression, chest tube insertion Pericardiocentesis, urgent thoracotomy Complications Cardiac arrest, death, tension physiology Cardiogenic shock, heart failure, death

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman undergoing mitral and aortic mechanical valve replacement exhibited severe refractory hypotension that began immediately after protamine reversal of intraoperative heparin anticoagulation following separation from cardiopulmonary bypass. Intraoperative trans-oesophageal echocardiography revealed severe thrombosis in the right atrium, right ventricle and pulmonary artery. The patient was managed by immediate re-heparinization and return to cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB), surgical thrombectomy, and intraoperative administration of recombinant tissue-plasminogen activator. Which of the following is not a potential complication of cardiopulmonary bypass?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Cardiopulmonary bypass provides cardiac and respiratory support when the function of the heart and lungs needs to be temporarily interrupted. Difficulties can occur during cannulation (aortic dissection or atrial injury), at the start of CPB (oxygenator failure) and at the end of CPB (coagulopathy). Many complications can occur following blood exposure to the non-physiological surface of the CPB circuit. This leads to the activation of inflammatory cascades giving rise to a post-CPB systematic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) that can ultimately lead to multiorgan failure.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Aortic dissection or atrial injury can occur during cannulation in CPB. Option: B. Coagulopathy can occur at the end of CPB. Option: C. Following blood exposure to the non-physiological surface of the CPB circuit, leads to the activation of inflammatory cascades giving rise to a post-CPB systematic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) that can ultimately lead to multiorgan failure.

questions.text: A 66-yr-old male was admitted through the emergency room complaining of chest pain and sustaining an acute inferior wall myocardial infarction. On the basis of cardiac catheterization, the patient was scheduled for coronary artery revascularization and possible aortic valve replacement. Cardiopulmonary bypass was initiated with a roller pump. During cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) anticoagulation, the range of heparin needed to increase the activated clotting time to greater than 450 seconds is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

300 to 400 units/kg Anticoagulation is required during CPB, and 300 to 400 units/kg of heparin is given to increase the activated clotting time (AC) to greater than 450 seconds. Once an adequate level of anticoagulation is achieved, arterial cannulation is performed through a purse-string suture or through a side graft sewn onto the native artery.

Highyeild:

A basic CPB (cardiopulmonary bypass) circuit consists of several components, including venous cannulae, a venous reservoir, pump, oxygenator, filter, and arterial cannula. During CPB, anticoagulation is required to prevent blood clotting, and heparin is typically given in a dose of 300-400 units/kg to increase the activated clotting time (ACT) to greater than 450 seconds. Once adequate anticoagulation is achieved, arterial cannulation is performed through a purse-string suture or side graft onto the native artery, typically at the distal ascending thoracic aorta (most common site), femoral artery, axillary artery, innominate artery, or distal aortic arch, depending on the surgical repair needed and presence of native arterial disease. Venous cannulation is performed through purse-string sutures placed on the right atrium or through a femoral vein with TEE guidance in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The purpose of the CPB circuit is to allow for temporary bypass of the heart and lungs during cardiac surgery, providing oxygenated blood to the body while the heart is stopped for repair.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with an altered exercise testing was addressed to a computed tomography coronary angiography (CTCA) to rule out coronary artery disease (CAD). What is the most common involved vessel in Coronary artery disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left Anterior Descending artery The LAD is the most frequently diseased coronary artery and most often bypassed during CABG surgery.

Highyeild:

Coronary angiography ● Gold standard for imaging coronary anatomy ● Demonstrates extent, severity and location of stenosis ● Demonstrates quality and size of distal arterial tree ● Aids diagnosis of ischaemia ● Evaluates suitability for surgery ● Aids in prognostic assessment

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Common sites of stenosis of the RCA are in its proximal portion or at the bifurcation or crux. Option: C. The posterior descending artery arises from right coronary artery in 90% of cases and is not commonly involved like LAD. Option: D. The circumflex artery is not commonly involved like LAD.

Extraedge:

Coronary angiogram showing a tight, critical stenosis in the proximal left anterior descending coronary artery (left); After placement of a bare-metal stent (right). Wellens syndrome

questions.text: A 47- year- old male with diabetes mellitus on stress ECHO shows regional wall motion abnormality. He was diagnosed with triple vessel disease on angiogram and advised for Coronary bypass surgery. Which sternotomy is done in CABG?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Median sternotomy The heart is approached mainly by a median sternotomy in Cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB).

Highyeild:

Parameter Antero-lateral thoracotomy Partial sternotomy Median sternotomy Postero- lateral thoracotomy Incision Location Anterior-lateral aspect of the chest, usually in the fourth or fifth intercostal space. Lower part of the sternum Through the midline of the sternum from the sternal notch to the xiphoid process. Posterolateral aspect of the chest, usually in the fifth or sixth intercostal space. Structures Accessed Lung, heart, great vessels, diaphragm, and esophagus Lower part of the heart, inferior vena cava, and pulmonary artery Heart, great vessels, and lungs. Lung, diaphragm, and chest wall. Advantages Provides good access to the anterior aspects of the chest; allows for bilateral exposure if needed. Minimally invasive; avoids cutting through the breastbone. Provides good access to the heart and great vessels; widely used for cardiac surgery Provides good access to the posterior aspects of the chest. Disadvantages Can be associated with significant pain and impaired respiratory function; may cause damage to the intercostal nerves and vessels Limited exposure and limited access to certain structures; may require conversion to a full sternotomy More invasive than other approaches; may cause significant pain and longer recovery time. Limited exposure and limited access to certain structures; may require conversion to a full thoracotomy Common Procedures Thoracotomy for lung resection, cardiac surgery. esophagectomy, and diaphragmatic repair. Mitral valve repair, aortic valve replacement, and other cardiac procedures Coronary artery bypass grafting, valve replacement, and other cardiac procedures Thoracotomy for lung resection, chest wall reconstruction and spinal surgery.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Anterolateral thoracotom y is done in emergency procedures following major chest trauma, or to allow direct access to the heart after a cardiac arrest. Option: B. Partial sternotomy is done in minimally invasive surgeries like Valve Replacement surgeries. Option: D . Posterio-lateral thoracotomy is the most common procedure and the usual method of gaining access to the lungs to remove a lung or a portion of a lung to treat lung cancer.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male developed supraventricular tachycardia, followed by ventricular tachycardia and asystole. Closed chest cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) was begun immediately, and multiple 1-mg doses of epinephrine were administered. The patient’s rhythm failed to stabilize, and he remained dependent on CPR for pulsatile flow. The decision was made to open the chest and perform an open-chest massage. The patient was heparinized and emergently cannulated for CPB support. What is the most common complication expected in this patient due to Cardiopulmonary bypass support?

options.label: A
options.text: Post- CPB systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)

questions.correct_answer: A. Post- CPB systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Post- CPB systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) Cardiopulmonary bypass provides cardiac and respiratory support when the function of the heart and lungs needs to be temporarily interrupted. Following the blood exposure to the non-physiological surface of the CPB circuit, inflammatory cascades are activated giving rise to a post-CPB systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) that can ultimately lead to multiorgan failure.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Post-pericardiotomy syndrome (PPS) is a clinical syndrome consisting of worsening or new formation of pericardial and/or pleural effusion, pericardial rub, chest pain with or without dyspnea, fever, and elevated inflammatory markers but is not as common as SIRS. Option: C. Coagulopathy can occur at the end of CPB but is not as common as SIRS. Option: D. Pulmonary injury after cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) is a common complication in patients undergoing cardiac surgery and is associated with low arterial oxygen tension (PaO2) or high carbon dioxide tension (PCO2), which can continue for several days, leading to prolonged mechanical ventilation but is not as common as SIRS.

questions.text: A 56-year-old physician contracted COVID-19 while caring for patients. Despite treatment, his condition continued to decline and he was placed on veno-venous extracorporeal life support. His lungs showed no improvement on ECLS and began to manifest signs of irreversible damage. Cardiopulmonary bypass was indicated for lung transplant surgery. What is the most common site for arterial cannulation in CPB?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Distal ascending thoracic aorta Once an adequate level of anticoagulation is achieved, arterial cannulation is performed. The distal ascending thoracic aorta is the most common site of cannulation. Other routinely utilized sites of cannulation include the femoral artery, the axillary artery, the innominate artery, or the distal aortic arch, and they are altered based on the indicated surgical repair and the presence of native arterial disease.

Highyeild:

A basic CPB (cardiopulmonary bypass) circuit consists of several components, including venous cannulae, a venous reservoir, pump, oxygenator, filter, and arterial cannula. The CPB machine is usually placed 50–70 cm below the level of the heart and oxygenated using an oxygenator that allows gas exchange across its membrane. During CPB, anticoagulation is required to prevent blood clotting, and heparin is typically given in a dose of 300-400 units/kg to increase the activated clotting time (ACT) to greater than 450 seconds. Once adequate anticoagulation is achieved, arterial cannulation is performed through a purse-string suture or side graft onto the native artery, typically at the distal ascending thoracic aorta (most common site), femoral artery, axillary artery, innominate artery, or distal aortic arch, depending on the surgical repair needed and presence of native arterial disease. Venous cannulation is performed through purse-string sutures placed on the right atrium or through a femoral vein with TEE guidance in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The purpose of the CPB circuit is to allow for temporary bypass of the heart and lungs during cardiac surgery, providing oxygenated blood to the body while the heart is stopped for repair.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Alternatively, when it is inadvisable (aortic dissection), impractical (aortic root surgery) or impossible (severe adhesions) to cannulate the aorta alternative arterial cannulation sites can be used, such as the femoral artery or the axillary artery. Option: B. The distal aortic arch can be used as an alternative based on the presence of native arterial disease. Option: D. The axillary artery can be used as an alternative based on the presence of native arterial disease. Axillary cannulation has the theoretical advantage of reducing thromboembolic events when compared to femoral cannulation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient, who has a known cardiac disease for almost 5 years had a ejection fraction of 45% in echocardiography. Coronary angiography findings are as follows: 95% of stenosis in the left anterior descending (LAD) and 70%–80% of stenosis in right coronary artery (RCA). On physical examination, crepitation was detected in the basal segments of the lungs. The patient had pain at rest and 2-3 mm of elevation was seen at the anterior derivations, which was seen at the ECG. The patient had unstable pain, coronary lesions were not suitable for PTCA procedure, and there were pre-shock findings. CABG was planned. What is the most common site for venous cannulation in CPB?

options.label: D
options.text: Superior vena cava and inferior vena cava

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right atrium Venous cannulation is performed through the right atrium either for a single cannula or for two separate cannulae placed into the superior and inferior vena cava, respectively.

Highyeild:

A basic CPB (cardiopulmonary bypass) circuit consists of several components, including venous cannulae, a venous reservoir, pump, oxygenator, filter, and arterial cannula. The CPB machine is usually placed 50–70 cm below the level of the heart and oxygenated using an oxygenator that allows gas exchange across its membrane. During CPB, anticoagulation is required to prevent blood clotting, and heparin is typically given in a dose of 300-400 units/kg to increase the activated clotting time (ACT) to greater than 450 seconds. Once adequate anticoagulation is achieved, arterial cannulation is performed through a purse-string suture or side graft onto the native artery, typically at the distal ascending thoracic aorta (most common site), femoral artery, axillary artery, innominate artery, or distal aortic arch, depending on the surgical repair needed and presence of native arterial disease. Venous cannulation is performed through purse-string sutures placed on the right atrium or through a femoral vein with TEE guidance in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The purpose of the CPB circuit is to allow for temporary bypass of the heart and lungs during cardiac surgery, providing oxygenated blood to the body while the heart is stopped for repair.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Venous drainage from the femoral vein can offer an alternative, particularly during thoracic aortic or minimally invasive procedures Option: B. The superior and inferior vena cavae may be cannulated separately to gain better control over the venous return and to facilitate surgery within the right atrium. Option: D. The superior and inferior vena cavae may be cannulated separately to gain better control over the venous return and to facilitate surgery within the right atrium and can be used as an alternative.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with severe hypothermia was presented at the operating room. After a car accident, she was immersed for about four hours before the Mobile Medical Team arrived. The patient arrived at the OR while resuscitation was being performed. She was immediately anesthetized and median sternotomy took place, followed by intrapericardial heart massage. Extracorporeal circulation was initiated after heparinization. The machine is placed at what distance below the level of the heart?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

50-70 cm Once the circuit is connected, the CPB machine (the ‘pump’) gradually takes over the processes of circulation and ventilation. The CPB machine is usually placed 50–70 cm below the level of the heart and oxygenated using an oxygenator that allows gas exchange across its membrane.

Highyeild:

A basic CPB (cardiopulmonary bypass) circuit consists of several components, including venous cannulae, a venous reservoir, pump, oxygenator, filter, and arterial cannula. The CPB machine is usually placed 50–70 cm below the level of the heart and oxygenated using an oxygenator that allows gas exchange across its membrane. During CPB, anticoagulation is required to prevent blood clotting, and heparin is typically given in a dose of 300-400 units/kg to increase the activated clotting time (ACT) to greater than 450 seconds. Once adequate anticoagulation is achieved, arterial cannulation is performed through a purse-string suture or side graft onto the native artery, typically at the distal ascending thoracic aorta (most common site), femoral artery, axillary artery, innominate artery, or distal aortic arch, depending on the surgical repair needed and presence of native arterial disease. Venous cannulation is performed through purse-string sutures placed on the right atrium or through a femoral vein with TEE guidance in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The purpose of the CPB circuit is to allow for temporary bypass of the heart and lungs during cardiac surgery, providing oxygenated blood to the body while the heart is stopped for repair.

questions.text: Non- ST-elevated myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) was diagnosed by electrocardiogram (EKG) in a 57 years-old female. The patient, underwent coronary angiogram, which showed critical stenosis of both left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery and first obtuse marginal (OM) coronary artery, and sub-occlusion of left circumflex (LCx) coronary artery. During intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) study, OM coronary artery was dissected and all the efforts accomplished in order to stabilize the anatomy with Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) failed due to retrograde progression of the dissection until both LCx and LAD coronary arteries. She underwent in emergency CABG surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass. Which of the following is the first step during cardiopulmonary bypass?

options.label: D
options.text: Blood is cooled to reduce BMR

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anticoagulation is achieved Anticoagulation is required during CPB, and 300 to 400 units/kg of heparin are given to increase the activated clotting time (ACT) to greater than 450 seconds. Once an adequate level of anticoagulation is achieved, arterial cannulation and venous cannulation are performed. Once the appropriate cannulations and connections are complete, CPB is commenced.

Highyeild:

A basic CPB (cardiopulmonary bypass) circuit consists of several components, including venous cannulae, a venous reservoir, pump, oxygenator, filter, and arterial cannula. The CPB machine is usually placed 50–70 cm below the level of the heart and oxygenated using an oxygenator that allows gas exchange across its membrane. During CPB, anticoagulation is required to prevent blood clotting, and heparin is typically given in a dose of 300-400 units/kg to increase the activated clotting time (ACT) to greater than 450 seconds. Once adequate anticoagulation is achieved, arterial cannulation is performed through a purse-string suture or side graft onto the native artery, typically at the distal ascending thoracic aorta (most common site), femoral artery, axillary artery, innominate artery, or distal aortic arch, depending on the surgical repair needed and presence of native arterial disease. Venous cannulation is performed through purse-string sutures placed on the right atrium or through a femoral vein with TEE guidance in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The purpose of the CPB circuit is to allow for temporary bypass of the heart and lungs during cardiac surgery, providing oxygenated blood to the body while the heart is stopped for repair.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Venous cannulation is performed after arterial cannulation. Option: B. Once an adequate level of anticoagulation is achieved, arterial cannulation is performed. Option: D. Once the appropriate cannulations and connections are complete, CPB is commenced and blood is cooled to reduce BMR.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman presented with complaints of chest pain and difficulty in breathing. Electrocardiogram (EKG) was immediately taken which showed normal sinus rhythm with nonspecific ST deviation. Cardiac enzyme levels were within normal limits with an increase in D-dimer. The chest radiograph showed mild mediastinal widening. The CT results showed aortic dissection type A starting from the distal ascending aorta with its distal extent just proximal to the right main renal artery. Emergency surgical correction along with Cardiopulmonary bypass was planned. What is the site for arterial cannulation in CPB in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Femoral artery The distal ascending thoracic aorta is the most common site of cannulation. Alternatively, when it is inadvisable (aortic dissection), impractical (aortic root surgery) or impossible (severe adhesions) to cannulate the aorta alternative arterial cannulation sites can be used, such as the femoral artery or the axillary artery. Axillary cannulation has the theoretical advantage of reducing thromboembolic events when compared to femoral cannulation.

Highyeild:

A basic CPB (cardiopulmonary bypass) circuit consists of several components, including venous cannulae, a venous reservoir, pump, oxygenator, filter, and arterial cannula. The CPB machine is usually placed 50–70 cm below the level of the heart and oxygenated using an oxygenator that allows gas exchange across its membrane. During CPB, anticoagulation is required to prevent blood clotting, and heparin is typically given in a dose of 300-400 units/kg to increase the activated clotting time (ACT) to greater than 450 seconds. Once adequate anticoagulation is achieved, arterial cannulation is performed through a purse-string suture or side graft onto the native artery, typically at the distal ascending thoracic aorta (most common site), femoral artery, axillary artery, innominate artery, or distal aortic arch, depending on the surgical repair needed and presence of native arterial disease. Venous cannulation is performed through purse-string sutures placed on the right atrium or through a femoral vein with TEE guidance in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The purpose of the CPB circuit is to allow for temporary bypass of the heart and lungs during cardiac surgery, providing oxygenated blood to the body while the heart is stopped for repair.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. The distal aortic arch can be used as an alternative based on the presence of native arterial disease. Option: C. The distal ascending thoracic aorta is the most common site of cannulation. Option: D. The innominate artery can be used as an alternative based on the presence of native arterial disease.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female with a history of intravenous drug use was found outdoors in a remote, wooded area. She was severely hypothermic with a GCS of 3. with a heart rate of 40 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 8 breaths per minute, an unmeasurable blood pressure and pulse oxygen saturation, and a rectal temperature of 19.8 °C. Her cardiac rhythm showed sinus bradycardia. The patient was observed to have episodes of cardiac dysrhythmia during her time in the ED. What is the indication for this patient to have Cardiopulmonary bypass?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Profound hypothermia Cardiopulmonary bypass can be employed in any procedure in which the heart and lungs need to be stopped temporarily and their function replaced artificially. Alternative uses of cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) include rewarming from profound hypothermia, resuscitation in severe respiratory failure, as an adjunct in pulmonary embolectomy, In in single- and double-lung transplantation, in cardiopulmonary trauma, in certain non-cardiac surgical procedures (e.g. resection of highly vascular tumours and tumours invading large blood vessels)

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Unmeasurable blood pressure is not an indication for CPB. Option: B. Sinus bradycardia is not an indication for CPB. Option: C. Cardiac dysrhythmia is not an indication for CPB.

questions.text: A 61-year-old male presenting with transient loss of consciousness. Electrocardiogram (EKG) demonstrated normal sinus rhythm Chest X-ray revealed widening of the mediastinum. His chest radiography indicated a widening of mediastinum, and contrast-enhanced chest CT demonstrated Stanford type A aortic dissection extending from the aortic root to the bifurcation of common iliac arteries. What is the site for arterial cannulation in CPB in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Axillary artery The distal ascending thoracic aorta is the most common site of cannulation. Alternatively, when it is inadvisable (aortic dissection), impractical (aortic root surgery) or impossible (severe adhesions) to cannulate the aorta alternative arterial cannulation sites can be used, such as the femoral artery or the axillary artery. Axillary cannulation has the theoretical advantage of reducing thromboembolic events when compared to femoral cannulation.

Highyeild:

A basic CPB (cardiopulmonary bypass) circuit consists of several components, including venous cannulae, a venous reservoir, pump, oxygenator, filter, and arterial cannula. The CPB machine is usually placed 50–70 cm below the level of the heart and oxygenated using an oxygenator that allows gas exchange across its membrane. During CPB, anticoagulation is required to prevent blood clotting, and heparin is typically given in a dose of 300-400 units/kg to increase the activated clotting time (ACT) to greater than 450 seconds. Once adequate anticoagulation is achieved, arterial cannulation is performed through a purse-string suture or side graft onto the native artery, typically at the distal ascending thoracic aorta (most common site), femoral artery, axillary artery, innominate artery, or distal aortic arch, depending on the surgical repair needed and presence of native arterial disease. Venous cannulation is performed through purse-string sutures placed on the right atrium or through a femoral vein with TEE guidance in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The purpose of the CPB circuit is to allow for temporary bypass of the heart and lungs during cardiac surgery, providing oxygenated blood to the body while the heart is stopped for repair.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The distal ascending thoracic aorta is the most common site of cannulation. Option: B. The distal aortic arch can be used as an alternative based on the presence of native arterial disease. Option: D. The innominate artery can be used as an alternative based on the presence of native arterial disease.

questions.text: A 32- year- male was diagnosed as a case of coronary artery disease not amenable to angioplasty, hence referred for bypass surgery. Since he is a young man with lean built, a decision was made to perform minimal invasive bypass surgery. What is the site for venous cannulation in CPB in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Superior vena cava and inferior vena cava

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Femoral vein Venous cannulation is performed through the right atrium either for a single cannula or for two separate cannulae placed into the superior and inferior vena cava, respectively. Alternatively, the superior and inferior vena cavae may be cannulated separately to gain better control over the venous return and to facilitate surgery within the right atrium. Venous drainage from the femoral vein can offer an alternative, particularly during thoracic aortic or minimally invasive procedures.

Highyeild:

A basic CPB (cardiopulmonary bypass) circuit consists of several components, including venous cannulae, a venous reservoir, pump, oxygenator, filter, and arterial cannula. The CPB machine is usually placed 50–70 cm below the level of the heart and oxygenated using an oxygenator that allows gas exchange across its membrane. During CPB, anticoagulation is required to prevent blood clotting, and heparin is typically given in a dose of 300-400 units/kg to increase the activated clotting time (ACT) to greater than 450 seconds. Once adequate anticoagulation is achieved, arterial cannulation is performed through a purse-string suture or side graft onto the native artery, typically at the distal ascending thoracic aorta (most common site), femoral artery, axillary artery, innominate artery, or distal aortic arch, depending on the surgical repair needed and presence of native arterial disease. Venous cannulation is performed through purse-string sutures placed on the right atrium or through a femoral vein with TEE guidance in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The purpose of the CPB circuit is to allow for temporary bypass of the heart and lungs during cardiac surgery, providing oxygenated blood to the body while the heart is stopped for repair.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The venous cannula may be inserted from the femoral vein and advanced into the right atrium and superior vena cava using TEE guidance. This technique is frequently used in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. Option: B. The superior and inferior vena cavae may be cannulated separately to gain better control over the venous return and to facilitate surgery within the right atrium. Option: D. The superior and inferior vena cavae may be cannulated separately to gain better control over the venous return and to facilitate surgery within the right atrium and can be used as an alternative.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Coronary Circulation of heart is FALSE:

options.label: A
options.text: The LAD is the most frequently diseased coronary artery and most often bypassed during CABG surgery.

options.label: B
options.text: The left coronary artery arises from the ostia in the left anterior sinus.

options.label: C
options.text: The worst prognosis in terms of survival without surgery is seen in ‘left main-stem coronary disease’.

options.label: D
options.text: A left-right coronary circulation anastomosis is formed at the junction of left & right atrium and the interventricular septum.

questions.correct_answer: B. The left coronary artery arises from the ostia in the left anterior sinus.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The left coronary artery arises from the ostia in the left anterior sinus. The heart is supplied by two coronary arteries, arising from the ascending aorta. Both arteries run in the coronary sulcus. Left coronary artery is larger than the right coronary artery.

Random:

Explanation For All Options:- Option:A. The LAD is the most frequently diseased coronary artery and most often bypassed during CABG surgery. Option:B. Left coronary artery arises from the left posterior aortic sinus of the ascending aorta. Right coronary artery arises from the anterior aortic sinus of the ascending aorta. Option:C. The worst prognosis in terms of survival without surgery is seen in ‘left main-stem coronary disease’ . Since, the artery is inaccessible at its origin, grafts are anastomosed to its branches, the left anterior descending artery (LAD) and left-marginal branch of the circumflex artery. Option:D. Though the branches of the left & right coronary artery anastomose with each other but one cannot compensate for the other artery in case of thrombosis. These arteries are functional end arteries.

Extraedge:

Coronary angiogram showing a tight, critical stenosis in the proximal left anterior descending

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with history of angina & dyspnoea (NYHA Class 2), came to the cardiology OPD and was planned for coronary angiography. In the imaging the patient was reported to have left dominant coronary circulation.Which of the following is true: 90% of cases the posterior descending artery arises from the LCA. The origin of posterior interventricular artery determines the dominance of the circulation. In this patient, LCA gives off the posterior descending artery, and artery to AV node. The dominance is said to be the one that supplies more of myocardium. So, 90% of cases are Left Dominant. Left coronary is larger in caliber and supplies more myocardium. Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B, D

Highyeild:

Coronary angiography Gold standard for imaging coronary anatomy Demonstrates extent, severity and location of stenosis Demonstrates quality and size of distal arterial tree Aids diagnosis of ischaemia Evaluates suitability for surgery Aids in prognostic assessment

Random:

Explanation For All Options:- Option: A. 90% of cases the posterior descending artery arises from the RCA. Option: B. The origin of the posterior interventricular artery determines the dominance of the artery, which arises from the RCA in 90%, a pattern referred to as RIGHT DOMINANCE. So, It is true that, in this patient, LCA gives off the Posterior descending artery since he has LEFT DOMINANT Circulation. In LEFT DOMINANT hearts, the circumflex artery, the continuation of left coronary, provides the posterior interventricular branch as well as to the AV node. Option: C. Left coronary is larger in caliber and supplies more myocardium, but even then, it is not the dominant one in 90% cases. Option: D. Left coronary is LARGER in caliber and supplies more of myocardium.

Extraedge:

Coronary angiogram showing a tight, critical stenosis in the proximal left anterior descending coronary artery (left); After placement of a bare-metal stent (right). Wellens syndrome

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with sudden onset chest pain, which is radiating to the left arm, is brought to the emergency by his relatives 30 minutes after the pain started. The patient is also sweating profusely, is light-headed, and also has shortness of breath. An urgent ECG revealed the following finding:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C The ECG shows prominent ST-elevation in V1-V4 , which are a finding in anterior wall MI. The artery most commonly involved in it is left anterior descending artery.

Random:

Explanation For All Options:- Option: A. (Artery Marked A) is right coronary artery . A block is rare and would cause inferior wall MI. Option: B. (Artery Marked C) is left anterior descending artery , which is involved in anterior wall MI. Option: C. (Artery Marked B) Posterior interventricular artery , which is involved in inferior wall MI. Option: D. (Artery Marked D) is the circumflex branch , which is involved in lateral wall MI.

questions.text: The following are the uses for the Cardiopulmonary Bypass System. Except:

options.label: D
options.text: In COVID Patients with Severe disease.

questions.correct_answer: D. In COVID Patients with Severe disease.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In COVID Patients with Severe disease.

Random:

Explanation For All Options:- Option: A. CPB or cardiopulmonary bypass is used in various Cardiac Surgeries. Option: B & C. The alternative uses of cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) are- Rewarming from profound hypothermia Resuscitation in severe respiratory failure As an adjunct in pulmonary embolectomy In single- and double-lung transplantation In cardiopulmonary trauma In certain non-cardiac surgical procedures (e.g., resection of highly vascular tumours and tumours invading large blood vessels) Option: D. In COVID Patients ECMO (Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation )is used. As ECMO can be used for longer duration.

questions.text: In a Patient in whom the cardiopulmonary bypass is being established, all of the following methods can be used to ensure the myocardial protection, except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Using Arterial Filters Once CPB has been established the ascending aorta is cross-clamped, the heart ceases to eject and becomes anoxic due to inhibition of coronary blood flow. Permanent myocardial damage can develop within 15–20 minutes, therefore most cardiac operations require some form of myocardial protection.

Random:

Explanation For All Options:- Option: A. Cardioplegic solutions. Most solutions contain potassium as the arresting agent. Potassium arrests the heart in diastole by depolarization of the myocyte cellular membrane Option: B. Arterial filter is used to remove particulate emboli before blood is returned to the systemic arterial circulation. Option: C. Intermittent cross-clamp fibrillation is a technique in which intermittent ventricular fibrillation is induced by a small electrical charge. The heart does not eject and is relatively still but not bloodless Option: D. Total circulatory arrest becomes necessary when visibility and clarity of the operative area is crucial. CPB is instituted and the core body temperature reduced to 15–18ºC .

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient undergoing CABG, requires to have a Cardiopulmonary Bypass to be established. The following are true regarding the Process of CPB: The patient is fully heparinised, prior to cannulation. Aortic perfusion cannula is inserted into the ascending aorta Venous cannulation is done at the right atrial appendage Arterial Cannula is a two-stage cannula. Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, & 3 are correct Statement:1. Before cannulation for CPB, the patient is fully heparinised . It prevents coagulopathy, which is a complication which can be seen at the end of CPB. Statement:2. Arterial cannulation can be placed in Ascending Aorta (Aortic cannula), Brachial Artery, or Femoral Artery. Statement:3. A purse-string suture is placed around the right atrial appendage, and venous cannula is placed to establish venous drainage. Statement:4. The venous cannula is “two-stage”. The venous pipe has end holes that sit in the inferior vena cava and side holes that sit in the right atrium (to take drainage from the superior vena cava).

questions.text: This machine was used during a particularly difficult cardiac surgery. In the following schematic diagram, identify the correct labelled part of the machine :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C - Venous reservoir The image depicts the components of the cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) circuit. Once the circuit is connected the CPB machine gradually takes over the processes of circulation and ventilation.
